transcripts.text: The wording of President Trump's 2012 address was bad and wrong.
That's all.  There are plenty of things that are bad and wrong, but it doesn't make them fascist.  Well...
I suppose that's true, but...

Imagine for a second you're heralded as one of the great intelligentsia of the right, a fast-talking smart man, and you go on, say, for instance, Fox News and call Sean Hannity a leftist who has obvious political biases.  And why can't they just be honest and just declare their obvious leftist biases?  Further, all of this is to promote a book which sneers at media for being too judgmental, too combative, too angry.  And that's what's wrong with America.  Now, normally, I'm not a fan of the but you're a hypocrite type arguments because it tends to be overused and shoehorned into places where it really isn't fit.  And it's kind of a by point in any event, because even if that's true, you're not debunking the original point that was made.
But Holy crap, Mr.
Shapiro here destroys the irony meter.  He pulls out levels of irony to blow up irony meters in parallel universes.

You purport to be an objective journalist.  BBC purports to be an objective down-the-middle network.  It obviously is not, it never has been, and you as a journalist are proceeding to call one side of the political aisle ignorant, barbaric, and sending us back to the dark ages.

Just so we're clear who he's talking to here, he's talking to Andrew Neil, a lifelong conservative and a pretty hawkish one too, who described the 2003 invasion of Iraq by Bush and Blair as convincing and masterful.
Yeah, it's pretty hawkish.
He also rejects the scientific consensus on climate change.
Why don't you just say that you're on the left?  Is this so hard for you?  Why can't you just be honest?  Seriously, it's a serious question.
Mr.  Shapiro, if you only knew how ridiculous that statement is, you wouldn't have said it.
Yeah, it's not quite as bad as going on Fox News and calling Hannity or Bill O'Reilly or something like that leftists.  But it's pretty close.
Mr.  Shapiro, if you only knew how ridiculous that statement is, you wouldn't have said it.  So let's move on.  Would you vote for Mr.
Trump?  I think it's pretty evident from your own questions exactly what you are saying.

So after this dumpster fire, Ben Shapiro takes to Twitter, just pre-taped an interview with BBC's Andrew Neil.  I'm not familiar with him or his work.  I misinterpreted his antagonism as political leftism.  which you're really going to wonder about because that means that to the right wing intelligentsia here.
We have a very strong debate that goes on inside sort of the conservative halls of intelligentsia.
Real journalism is almost indistinguishable from political leftism.  I think that puts you in the realm of.  everyone who disagrees with me is a radical leftist.
But my point is your book claims...
Well, it would be nice if you would quote it from time to time.

As you say in your book, you say there's quite a key phrase, we are so angry at each other right now.  Well, actually, I've done so several times and I'm about to do so again.  if you would let me just finish the question.
Yeah, Ben doesn't take so well to these burns, and that's when he ragequits.
Your book claims that society is turning its back on Judeo-Christian... Let me just stress that.

He ragequits an interview about this book he's written, saying that we need to be more grown-up, mature, and responsible in our debates, and not so angry and histrionic and making bad assumptions about people.

What I'm talking about is the assumption that people with whom we disagree politically are inherently of bad character.  I, you know, I'm not inclined to continue an interview with a person as badly motivated as you as an interviewer.
Yeah, you see what I mean about hypocrisy that blows up irony meters in parallel universes.  But Neil's final burn is devastating.  All right.
Well, thank you for your time and for showing that anger is not part of American political discourse.  Now, Mr Shapiro, we'll say goodbye.

It's also quite fun to see Ben Shapiro implementing some of the tactics from Yes Minister and Yes Prime Minister, which, by the way, was an incredibly entertaining comedy that tells you absolutely everything you need to know about politics.  This is what they had to say about how to do an interview.  or attack the interviewer.  Say, you clearly have never read the white paper itself, have you?
It obviously is not, it never has been, and you as a journalist are proceeding to call one side of the political aisle ignorant, barbaric, and sending us back to the dark ages.
Not quite.  This is what he actually said.
Georgia, new abortion laws, which you are much in favor of, that a woman who miscarries could get 30 years.
Actually, yes, that does seem pretty extreme.  And to be fair, Andrew Neil prefaced it with this comment.
Some of the ideas that are popular in your side of politics would seem to take us back to the dark ages.
Yeah, Ben, that does seem to be taking us back to the dark ages.  I mean, I wouldn't want to lecture on Judeo-Christian culture or anything.
You're lecturing me on Judeo-Christian culture after you called the pro-life position barbaric?

Yes, Judeo-Christian culture, all based on a guy called Abraham, who was famous because he heard voices in his head telling him he should kill his son.  And because that voice said it was God, he was happy to do it.
Yes, I believe that if you are somebody who takes Judaism seriously, that comes along with ideological commitment.

So tell me, Ben, what's your position on people who hear a voice in their head that claims to be God telling them to kill their kids?  Is that a moral good thing or a moral bad thing?  Maybe you can ask William Lane Craig when you next see him.  You know, the guy who said that all the children in the Bible who were killed in bloody slaughters and genocides were actually receiving an ultimate good and blessing because then they could be with God.

Moreover, if you believe as I do in the salvation of infants or children who die, what that meant was that the death of these children meant their salvation.  They were the recipients of an infinite good as a result of their earthly phase of life being terminated.

Which does kind of beg the question, Ben, if you actually believed any of this voodoo.  What's your problem with abortion here?  I mean, according to William Lane Craig here, abortion is just sending children to paradise before they're even born.  Why isn't that a good thing?
That a bill banning abortions after a woman has been pregnant for six weeks is not a return to the dark ages.  What's your answer?
My answer is something called science.
Anyway, back to Yes Minister and how to sneakily avoid answering questions in interviews.  Or else ask your own question, like, that was a very interesting question, now let me ask you a question.
Now back to my question to you.  Sir, I'm happy to answer your question, please answer this one.  And I asked you a question, you failed to answer a single one of mine.

Well, it's either he's being dishonest, or he doesn't actually understand the dynamics of an interview.  Which is, the interviewer asks questions, and the interviewee gives answers.  Because the interviewer isn't there to answer questions.  He's there to ask the pertinent questions to get interesting answers.
I'm interested that you think there's a thought movement inside the Republican Party.  I mean, haven't the Conservatives...

Now, Ben's response to this is just sort of, what are we saying about the hypocrisy?  He goes on to sort of say, yes, all the ideas of the left here, you know, this Medicare and minimum wage stuff, these aren't new ideas, which is true enough.  But then he goes on to say, but the right is full of great new ideas, like...

Now, there's a rich intellectual debate on the right about nationalism versus patriotism, for example, or populism versus free marketeerism.  I mean, frankly, I'm confused by the idea that any of those are particularly new ideas.  I mean, most of those ideas have been around since Franklin Delano Roosevelt at the very earliest.  The conservative halls of intelligentsia about what is the appropriate action to take with regard to the medical system.  That debate is happening on the right to sort of suggest that the right in America is bereft of ideas, but the left is full of ideas.  I think that it is intellectual sneering of the highest order to suggest that only the left has new and decent ideas.

Yes, and it's only fair to point out, Ben, that dismissing the left for discussing old ideas while claiming that the right wing is full of intelligentsia for discussing the same old ideas is the first-grade pseudo-intellectualism of a partisan hack.

Most of those ideas have been around since Franklin Delano Roosevelt at the very earliest, or at the very latest, rather.  Some of them go all the way back to Woodrow Wilson.  But the idea that new ideas are absent in the Republican Party is obviously untrue.
But a little more on the intellectual dishonesty.  Here, Ben is piously going on about how we shouldn't coarsen the public discourse.  And he gets called out for it like this.
Your YouTube videos, Ben Shapiro destroys the abortion argument.  Ben Shapiro destroys transgenderism.  Is that not a kind of coarse public discourse?
Are those videos labeled by me?

Wow, someone couldn't check you in real time, so that was your way of dotting the question.  If only there was some way we could fact-check this by maybe going to Ben Shapiro's YouTube channel and doing a search for the word destroys.  And we get Ben Shapiro destroys Piers Morgan.  Ben Shapiro destroys transgenderism.  Ben Shapiro destroys... Oh, I'm feeling the coarse thing in the public discourse coming up in my veins.  Ben Shapiro smacks down.  Ben Shapiro crashes.  Yeah, that's the way that we are.  Don't coarsen the public discourse, Ben.  But don't worry, I'm sure that the right-wing intelligentsia here isn't going to go all high school on us.
And then hitting people with them is a way for you to make a quick buck on BBC off the fact that I'm popular and no one has ever heard of you.
Which is followed by another sick burn.
There are not many bucks to be made on the BBC unlike American broadcasting, Mr.  Shapiro.
But poor Benny can't leave it alone.  And a few minutes later, he's back to the, but I'm more popular than you, argument.
I don't frankly give a damn what you think of me since I've never heard of you.  Bravo.
My intelligentsia has never heard of you.  So you must be wrong.  Bravo, Benny.  That's beautiful.
